comment: When a metal reacts with an acid, a salt is generally formed. \( \text{NaCl} \), \( \text{AlCl}_3 \), and \( \text{MgCl}_2 \) can all be formed by such reactions. However, \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) cannot be directly obtained in this way due to the specific chemical properties of iron and the oxidation states involved. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Metal materials have always played an important role in the development of human society. The earliest metal used in human history is
A. Cu
B. Fe
C. Al
D. Sn
choices: A. Cu
B. Fe
C. Al
D. Sn
comment: Copper (Cu) was one of the earliest metals used by humans. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question:
When an iron sheet is placed in the following solutions, the iron sheet dissolves and the mass of the solution increases, but no gas is released. Which one is it?
A. Dilute \\ce{H2SO4}
B. Copper(II) sulfate solution
C. Iron(III) sulfate solution
D. Silver nitrate solution
choices: A. Dilute \\ce{H2SO4}
B. Copper(II) sulfate solution
C. Iron(III) sulfate solution
D. Silver nitrate solution
comment: When iron is placed in dilute \\ce{H2SO4}, \\ce{H2} gas is released. In copper(II) sulfate solution, copper is deposited, and the solution does not gain mass. In iron(III) sulfate solution, iron dissolves and the mass of the solution increases without gas release. In silver nitrate solution, \\ce{Ag} is deposited and the solution does not gain mass. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
Which of the following statements about oxygen is incorrect?
A.  When preparing oxygen in the laboratory, a catalyst must be added.
B.  Sulfur burns in oxygen, producing a blue-purple flame.
C.  In the case of an oil pan fire, it can be extinguished using a lid, based on the principle of isolating air.
D.  Oxygen can react with most metals and certain compounds, and its chemical properties are relatively active.
choices: A.  When preparing oxygen in the laboratory, a catalyst must be added.
B.  Sulfur burns in oxygen, producing a blue-purple flame.
C.  In the case of an oil pan fire, it can be extinguished using a lid, based on the principle of isolating air.
D.  Oxygen can react with most metals and certain compounds, and its chemical properties are relatively active.
comment: When preparing oxygen in the laboratory, the addition of a catalyst is not always required. For example, heating potassium chlorate (\(\text{KClO}_3\)) with manganese dioxide (\(\text{MnO}_2\)) as a catalyst is one method, but other methods may not require a catalyst. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question:
When the following metals are separately added into 0.1 mol·L^{-1} hydrochloric acid, which metal reacts and reacts most vigorously?
A. Fe
B. Al
C. Mg
D. Cu
choices: A. Fe
B. Al
C. Mg
D. Cu
comment: Magnesium (\ce{Mg}) reacts most vigorously with hydrochloric acid compared to the other metals. The reaction produces hydrogen gas \ce{H2} and magnesium chloride \ce{MgCl2}, and it proceeds more rapidly than the reactions of \ce{Fe}, \ce{Al}, and \ce{Cu}. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
Which of the following preparations is not suitable for industrial production?
A.  In the preparation of laundry detergent, the number of carbon atoms in alkylbenzene sulfonate is preferably between 12 and 18.
B.  The purpose of refining pig iron is to appropriately reduce the carbon content in pig iron and remove most of the impurities such as sulfur and phosphorus.
C.  Extracting magnesium from seawater by electrolysis of molten magnesium oxide to produce metallic magnesium.
D.  Compared with the Haber process, the advantage of the joint process is that it improves the atomic utilization rate of the raw materials.
choices: A.  In the preparation of laundry detergent, the number of carbon atoms in alkylbenzene sulfonate is preferably between 12 and 18.
B.  The purpose of refining pig iron is to appropriately reduce the carbon content in pig iron and remove most of the impurities such as sulfur and phosphorus.
C.  Extracting magnesium from seawater by electrolysis of molten magnesium oxide to produce metallic magnesium.
D.  Compared with the Haber process, the advantage of the joint process is that it improves the atomic utilization rate of the raw materials.
comment: Electrolyzing molten magnesium oxide to extract magnesium from seawater is not an industrially feasible method for producing metallic magnesium. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
In 1942, Chinese scientist Hou Debang invented the world-famous 'Hou's process', which became an important method for producing pure alkali globally. The main chemical principle is as follows: \[ \text{NaCl} + \text{NH}_3 + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{CO}_2 \rightarrow \text{NH}_4\text{Cl} + \text{NaHCO}_3 \] \[ 2\text{NaHCO}_3 \xrightarrow{\Delta} \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{CO}_2 \] In this process, what property of \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) is demonstrated?
A.  Acidity
B.  Alkalinity
C.  Water solubility
D.  Thermal instability
choices: A.  Acidity
B.  Alkalinity
C.  Water solubility
D.  Thermal instability
comment: In the thermal decomposition reaction \( 2\text{NaHCO}_3 \xrightarrow{\Delta} \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + \text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{CO}_2 \), \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) breaks down under heating, demonstrating its thermal instability. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
The famous Chinese chemical expert Hou Debang established the "Hou's Soda Production Method" in the 1920s, which is renowned worldwide. In "Hou's Soda Production Method," the soda refers to which of the following?
A. \(\text{NaOH}\)
B. \(\text{K}_2\text{CO}_3\)
C. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\)
D. \(\text{NaHCO}_3\)
choices: A. \(\text{NaOH}\)
B. \(\text{K}_2\text{CO}_3\)
C. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\)
D. \(\text{NaHCO}_3\)
comment: In "Hou's Soda Production Method," the soda refers to sodium carbonate \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), which is the correct answer. Hence, the answer is C.

question:
Which of the following statements related to chemistry is incorrect?
A. In the Solvay process, the difference in solubility of substances is utilized.
B. Concentrated hydrochloric acid-soaked cotton can be used to test for leaks in nitrogen gas pipes.
C. Phosphorus is an essential trace element for the human body, so it is important to consume foods rich in phosphoric acid.
D. Gunpowder is made by mixing sulfur, saltpeter, and charcoal in a certain ratio.
choices: A. In the Solvay process, the difference in solubility of substances is utilized.
B. Concentrated hydrochloric acid-soaked cotton can be used to test for leaks in nitrogen gas pipes.
C. Phosphorus is an essential trace element for the human body, so it is important to consume foods rich in phosphoric acid.
D. Gunpowder is made by mixing sulfur, saltpeter, and charcoal in a certain ratio.
comment: Phosphorus is indeed an essential trace element, but phosphoric acid is not a dietary source of phosphorus. The statement in option C is incorrect.

question:
Under certain conditions, a substance weighing \( w \, \mathrm{g} \) undergoes complete combustion in sufficient oxygen. The combustion products immediately react with an excess amount of \( \mathrm{Na_2O_2} \), resulting in an increase in solid mass by \( w \; \mathrm{g} \). Which of the following mixtures does the substance belong to?
A.  None of them
B.  Only \( \mathrm{H_2} \) and \( \mathrm{CO} \)
C.  Only \( \mathrm{H_2} \), \( \mathrm{CO} \), and \( \mathrm{CO_2} \)
D.  All of them
choices: A.  None of them
B.  Only \( \mathrm{H_2} \) and \( \mathrm{CO} \)
C.  Only \( \mathrm{H_2} \), \( \mathrm{CO} \), and \( \mathrm{CO_2} \)
D.  All of them
comment: The combustion products react with \( \mathrm{Na_2O_2} \), forming \( \mathrm{CO_2} \) and \( \mathrm{H_2O} \), which increase the mass of the solid by \( w \; \mathrm{g} \). This indicates that the mixture contains all the given compounds: \( \mathrm{H_2} \), \( \mathrm{CO} \), \( \mathrm{CO_2} \), and \( \mathrm{C_6H_{12}O_6} \). Thus, the correct answer is D.

question:
Which of the following descriptions about \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) is correct?
A. Both are white solids.
B. Their molar masses are the same.
C. Both react with water to form a strong alkaline solution.
D. Both react with water to produce \( \text{O}_2 \).
choices: A. Both are white solids.
B. Their molar masses are the same.
C. Both react with water to form a strong alkaline solution.
D. Both react with water to produce \( \text{O}_2 \).
comment: Both \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) react with water to form \( \text{NaOH} \), which is a strong alkaline solution. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
A research group is investigating the reactivity of \ce{Ti}, \ce{Mg}, and \ce{Cu}. Under the same conditions, pieces of the same size of these three metals are placed separately into sufficient amounts of dilute sulfuric acid with the same concentration. The observations are as follows:\newline \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline Metal & \ce{Ti} & \ce{Mg} & \ce{Cu} \\ \hline Surface Phenomenon & Gas bubbles released slowly & Gas bubbles released quickly & No change \\ \hline \end{tabular} \newline Which of the following statements about the three metals is correct?
A.  The order of reactivity from strong to weak is \ce{Ti}, \ce{Mg}, \ce{Cu}.
B.  If \ce{Mg} is mixed with \ce{Ti} powder, dilute acid can be used to remove \ce{Mg} when purifying \ce{Ti}.
C.  Using \ce{Ti} to displace \ce{Cu} from \ce{CuSO4} solution is a good industrial method to obtain \ce{Cu}.
D.  At room temperature, \ce{Ti} and \ce{MgCl2} solution cannot undergo a displacement reaction.
choices: A.  The order of reactivity from strong to weak is \ce{Ti}, \ce{Mg}, \ce{Cu}.
B.  If \ce{Mg} is mixed with \ce{Ti} powder, dilute acid can be used to remove \ce{Mg} when purifying \ce{Ti}.
C.  Using \ce{Ti} to displace \ce{Cu} from \ce{CuSO4} solution is a good industrial method to obtain \ce{Cu}.
D.  At room temperature, \ce{Ti} and \ce{MgCl2} solution cannot undergo a displacement reaction.
comment: The reactivity order is \ce{Mg} > \ce{Ti} > \ce{Cu} based on the given observations. \ce{Mg} is the most reactive as it releases gas quickly, \ce{Ti} is less reactive as it releases gas slowly, and \ce{Cu} does not react. Therefore, D is correct because \ce{Ti} cannot displace \ce{Mg} from \ce{MgCl2}.

question:
Which of the following statements about \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) is correct?
A.  It can react with acid to release \( \text{CO}_2 \).
B.  Its solubility at the same temperature is greater than that of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \).
C.  Its thermal stability is better than \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \).
D.  Its common name is soda.
choices: A.  It can react with acid to release \( \text{CO}_2 \).
B.  Its solubility at the same temperature is greater than that of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \).
C.  Its thermal stability is better than \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \).
D.  Its common name is soda.
comment: The correct statement is that \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) can react with acid to release \( \text{CO}_2 \).

question:
Regarding the comparison between \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \), which of the following statements is incorrect?
A. \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solid readily decomposes upon heating, while \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) solid does not decompose easily upon heating.
B. Equal masses of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) react with sufficient amounts of hydrochloric acid, and the former consumes more moles of hydrochloric acid than the latter.
C. Equal molar concentrations of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solutions are each added with 2 drops of phenolphthalein solution, and the former shows a deeper color than the latter.
D. The ionic equations of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) solution and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solution reacting with \( \text{Ba(OH)}_2 \) solution are identical.
choices: A. \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solid readily decomposes upon heating, while \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) solid does not decompose easily upon heating.
B. Equal masses of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) react with sufficient amounts of hydrochloric acid, and the former consumes more moles of hydrochloric acid than the latter.

C. Equal molar concentrations of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solutions are each added with 2 drops of phenolphthalein solution, and the former shows a deeper color than the latter.
D. The ionic equations of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) solution and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solution reacting with \( \text{Ba(OH)}_2 \) solution are identical.
comment: The ionic equations of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) solution and \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) solution reacting with \( \text{Ba(OH)}_2 \) solution are not identical. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) produces \( \text{BaCO}_3 \), while \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) may also produce \( \text{Ba(HCO}_3)_2 \). Thus, the correct answer is D.

question:
From the history of metal utilization, it was first the Bronze Age, then the Iron Age, and the use of aluminum is a matter of recent years. This sequence is related to which of the following?
A. 1 and 3
B. 2 and 5
C. 3 and 5
D. 2 and 4
choices: A. 1 and 3
B. 2 and 5
C. 3 and 5
D. 2 and 4
comment: The sequence of metal utilization is related to the difficulty of metal extraction. Easier to extract metals were used earlier. Therefore, the correct answer is 2 and 4, which corresponds to option D.

question:
In fact, many non-metal oxides can react with \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) under certain conditions, and the reactions are highly regular. For example: \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + \text{SO}_2 = \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 \), \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{SO}_3 = 2\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 + \text{O}_2 \). Based on this, which of the following reaction equations are correct?
A. ① \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{Mn}_2\text{O}_7 = 4\text{NaMnO}_4 + \text{O}_2 \uparrow \)
B. ② \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{NO}_2 = 2\text{NaNO}_2 + \text{O}_2 \)
C. ③ \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{N}_2\text{O}_3 = 4\text{NaNO}_2 + \text{O}_2 \)
D. ④ \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{N}_2\text{O}_4 = 4\text{NaNO}_3 \)
choices: A. ① \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{Mn}_2\text{O}_7 = 4\text{NaMnO}_4 + \text{O}_2 \uparrow \)
B. ② \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{NO}_2 = 2\text{NaNO}_2 + \text{O}_2 \)
C. ③ \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{N}_2\text{O}_3 = 4\text{NaNO}_2 + \text{O}_2 \)
D. ④ \( 2\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2\text{N}_2\text{O}_4 = 4\text{NaNO}_3 \)
comment: ① is correct because \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) reacts with \( \text{Mn}_2\text{O}_7 \) to produce \( \text{NaMnO}_4 \) and release \( \text{O}_2 \). ④ is correct because \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) reacts with \( \text{N}_2\text{O}_4 \) to produce \( \text{NaNO}_3 \). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
To observe the flame color of burning ammonia gas, the best material for the gas guide tube should be
A. Sodium glass
B. Potassium glass
C. Quartz glass
D. Copper tube
choices: A. Sodium glass
B. Potassium glass
C. Quartz glass
D. Copper tube
comment: Quartz glass has high thermal resistance and excellent chemical stability, making it the most suitable material for observing the flame color of burning ammonia gas. Thus, the correct answer is C.

question:
When a substance is heated, the flame reaction is yellow. Which of the following judgments is correct?
A. The substance must be a compound of \( \text{Na} \).
B. The substance must contain the element \( \text{Na} \).
C. The substance must be metallic \( \text{Na} \).
D. It is certain that the substance contains the element \( \text{Cu} \).
choices: A. The substance must be a compound of \( \text{Na} \).
B. The substance must contain the element \( \text{Na} \).
C. The substance must be metallic \( \text{Na} \).
D. It is certain that the substance contains the element \( \text{Cu} \).
comment: A yellow flame reaction indicates the presence of sodium (\( \text{Na} \)). Therefore, the correct judgment is that the substance must contain the element \( \text{Na} \), making choice B correct.

question:
There are four metals A, B, C, and D. When A and B are placed in hydrochloric acid solutions of the same concentration, B reacts more vigorously than A. When A and D are connected with a wire and immersed in the hydrochloric acid solution, A gradually dissolves while bubbles form on D. When copper is immersed in the salt solution of D, there is no significant change, but when copper is immersed in the salt solution of C, metal C precipitates. The order of activity of A, B, C, and D from strongest to weakest is:
A. A > B > D > C
B. B > A > D > C
C. C > D > A > B
D. B > A > C > D
choices: A. A > B > D > C
B. B > A > D > C
C. C > D > A > B
D. B > A > C > D
comment: The order of metal activity can be determined by their reactivity with acids and their ability to displace other metals. Since B reacts more vigorously than A with hydrochloric acid, B is more active than A. A gradually dissolves while connected to D in the acid solution, indicating A is more active than D. Copper can displace C from its salt solution but not D, meaning C is more active than D. Thus, the correct order is B > A > D > C, and the correct answer is B.

question:
The flame effects of 'footprints', 'smile', and 'five rings' during the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics were even more spectacular and romantic. This is related to the 'flame color reaction' in high school chemistry. Which of the following statements is correct?
A.  The flame of non-metallic elements burning is generally colorless.
B.  The flame of all metals and their compounds burning is generally colored.
C.  The flame color reaction is generally observed through cobalt blue glass.
D.  The flame colors of \( \text{NaCl} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) when burned are the same.
choices: A.  The flame of non-metallic elements burning is generally colorless.
B.  The flame of all metals and their compounds burning is generally colored.
C.  The flame color reaction is generally observed through cobalt blue glass.
D.  The flame colors of \( \text{NaCl} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) when burned are the same.
comment: Sodium compounds, such as \( \text{NaCl} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \), produce the same yellow flame color during the flame color reaction. Hence, the correct answer is D.

question:
A platinum wire is used to extract a colorless solution. When it is burned in a colorless flame, a yellow flame is observed. Which of the following descriptions is correct?
A. Only contains \(\text{Na}^+\)
B. Must contain \(\text{Na}^+\) and may also contain \(\text{K}^+\)
C. Contains both \(\text{Na}^+\) and \(\text{K}^+\)
D. May contain either \(\text{Na}^+\) or \(\text{K}^+\)
choices: A. Only contains \(\text{Na}^+\)
B. Must contain \(\text{Na}^+\) and may also contain \(\text{K}^+\)
C. Contains both \(\text{Na}^+\) and \(\text{K}^+\)
D. May contain either \(\text{Na}^+\) or \(\text{K}^+\)
comment: The yellow flame observed indicates the presence of \(\text{Na}^+\) ions. \(\text{K}^+\) ions also give a flame color, but it is weaker and can be masked by the intense yellow of \(\text{Na}^+\). Therefore, the solution must contain \(\text{Na}^+\) and may also contain \(\text{K}^+\). The correct answer is B.

question:
When a certain substance is burned, the flame reaction is yellow. Which of the following statements is correct?
A. The substance must be a compound of \(\text{Na}\).
B. The substance must contain the element \(\text{Na}\).
C. The substance must be metallic \(\text{Na}\).
D. It can be confirmed that the substance does not contain the element \(\text{Na}\).
choices: A. The substance must be a compound of \(\text{Na}\).
B. The substance must contain the element \(\text{Na}\).
C. The substance must be metallic \(\text{Na}\).
D. It can be confirmed that the substance does not contain the element \(\text{Na}\).
comment: A yellow flame indicates the presence of sodium (\(\text{Na}\)). Therefore, the substance must contain the element \(\text{Na}\). The correct answer is B.

question:
A clean platinum wire is dipped into a colorless solution and subjected to a flame test. When directly observed, the flame appears yellow. When observed through cobalt blue glass, the flame appears light purple. Which of the following descriptions about this colorless solution is correct?
A.  It must contain \( \text{Na}^+ \), and cannot contain \( \text{K}^+ \).
B.  It must contain \( \text{K}^+ \), and may contain \( \text{Na}^+ \).
C.  It must contain \( \text{Na}^+ \), and may contain \( \text{K}^+ \).
D.  It contains both \( \text{K}^+ \) and \( \text{Na}^+ \).
choices: A.  It must contain \( \text{Na}^+ \), and cannot contain \( \text{K}^+ \).
B.  It must contain \( \text{K}^+ \), and may contain \( \text{Na}^+ \).
C.  It must contain \( \text{Na}^+ \), and may contain \( \text{K}^+ \).
D.  It contains both \( \text{K}^+ \) and \( \text{Na}^+ \).
comment: In the flame test, \( \text{Na}^+ \) produces a yellow flame, while \( \text{K}^+ \) produces a light purple flame when observed through cobalt blue glass. As both yellow and light purple colors are observed, the solution must contain both \( \text{Na}^+ \) and \( \text{K}^+ \). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Zinc powder is an essential material in fireworks, flash powder, and flares. Industrially, zinc powder is produced by condensing zinc vapor in certain gases. The following gases are given: \( ① \text{ Air}, ② \text{ CO}_2, ③ \text{ Ar}, ④ \text{ H}_2, ⑤ \text{ N}_2 \). Which of these can act as cooling gases?
A. ① and ②
B. ② and ③
C. ③ and ④
D. ④ and ⑤
choices: A. ① and ②
B. ② and ③
C. ③ and ④
D. ④ and ⑤
comment: Both \( \text{Ar} \) (③) and \( \text{H}_2 \) (④) are inert or suitable gases for condensing zinc vapor without causing unwanted reactions. Hence, the correct answer is C.

question:
Sodium \((\text{Na})\) and aluminum \((\text{Al})\) are both relatively active metals. Which of the following descriptions is incorrect?
A.  Both sodium \((\text{Na})\) and aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can burn vigorously in oxygen \((\text{O}_2)\), emitting dazzling light.
B.  Aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can react with dilute hydrochloric acid \((\text{HCl})\), dilute sulfuric acid \((\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4)\), and strong alkalis.
C.  Sodium \((\text{Na})\) can react with carbon dioxide \((\text{CO}_2)\) under heating conditions, and aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can react with ferric oxide \((\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3)\) under certain conditions in a displacement reaction.
D.  The thermite reaction involves sodium \((\text{Na})\) and a mixture of aluminum powder \((\text{Al})\) with ferric oxide \((\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3)\).
choices: A.  Both sodium \((\text{Na})\) and aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can burn vigorously in oxygen \((\text{O}_2)\), emitting dazzling light.
B.  Aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can react with dilute hydrochloric acid \((\text{HCl})\), dilute sulfuric acid \((\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4)\), and strong alkalis.

C.  Sodium \((\text{Na})\) can react with carbon dioxide \((\text{CO}_2)\) under heating conditions, and aluminum \((\text{Al})\) can react with ferric oxide \((\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3)\) under certain conditions in a displacement reaction.
D.  The thermite reaction involves sodium \((\text{Na})\) and a mixture of aluminum powder \((\text{Al})\) with ferric oxide \((\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3)\).
comment: The thermite reaction does not involve sodium \((\text{Na})\). It specifically involves aluminum \((\text{Al})\) powder and ferric oxide \((\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3)\). Therefore, option D is incorrect.

question:
There are four metal pieces A, B, C, and D. The following experiment is conducted: ① A and B are connected with a wire and immersed in dilute \ce{H2SO4}, A acts as the negative electrode; ② C and D are connected with a wire and immersed in dilute \ce{H2SO4}, electric current flows from D to C; ③ B and C are connected and immersed in dilute \ce{H2SO4}, C produces a large amount of gas bubbles; ④ B and D are connected and immersed in dilute \ce{H2SO4}, D produces a large amount of gas bubbles. Based on this, determine the order of activity of the four metals.
A. A, A > B > C > D
B. B, A > C > D > B
C. C, C > A > B > D
D. D, B > D > C > A
choices: A. A, A > B > C > D
B. B, A > C > D > B
C. C, C > A > B > D
D. D, B > D > C > A
comment: In experiment ①, since A acts as the negative electrode, A is more active than B. In experiment ②, since the electric current flows from D to C, D is more active than C. In experiment ③, since C produces gas bubbles, C is more active than B. In experiment ④, since D produces gas bubbles, D is more active than B. Therefore, the order of activity is A > B > C > D, making the correct answer A.

question:
Equal masses of zinc and aluminum react with sufficient hydrochloric acid respectively. The volume ratio of hydrogen gas produced is
A. 1:1
B. 1:2
C. 2:3
D. 3:4
comment: The molar mass of \( \text{Zn} \) is 65.38 g/mol and for \( \text{Al} \) is 26.98 g/mol. When they react with hydrochloric acid, the reactions are: \[ \text{Zn} + 2\text{HCl} \rightarrow \text{ZnCl}_2 + \text{H}_2 \] \[ 2\text{Al} + 6\text{HCl} \rightarrow 2\text{AlCl}_3 + 3\text{H}_2 \] For equal masses, \( n_{\text{Zn}} = \frac{m}{65.38} \) and \( n_{\text{Al}} = \frac{m}{26.98} \). The hydrogen volume ratio from \( \text{Zn} \) to \( \text{Al} \) is \( \frac{n_{\text{Zn}}}{n_{\text{Al}}} = \frac{26.98}{65.38} \times \frac{3}{1} = \frac{3}{4} \). So, the correct answer is D.

question:
After magnesium strips are burned in air, which of the following substances may be present in the product?
A. $\mathrm{MgCO_3}$, $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{Mg_3N_2}$
B. $\mathrm{Mg(OH)_2}$, $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{MgCO_3}$
C. $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{Mg_3N_2}$, C
D. $\mathrm{Mg_2N_3}$, C, $\mathrm{MgO}$
choices: A. $\mathrm{MgCO_3}$, $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{Mg_3N_2}$
B. $\mathrm{Mg(OH)_2}$, $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{MgCO_3}$
C. $\mathrm{MgO}$, $\mathrm{Mg_3N_2}$, C
D. $\mathrm{Mg_2N_3}$, C, $\mathrm{MgO}$
comment: When magnesium burns in air, it reacts with oxygen to form $\mathrm{MgO}$ and with nitrogen to form $\mathrm{Mg_3N_2}$. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
A mixture of magnesium, aluminum, and ferric metal powders reacts with an excess of hydrochloric acid. After filtering, an excess of sodium hydroxide solution is added to the filtrate, and then it is filtered again. Which ions are present in the final filtrate?
A. $\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}$
B. $\mathrm{AlO_2^-}$
C. $\mathrm{Al^{3+}}$
D. $\mathrm{Fe^{2+}}$
choices: A. $\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}$
B. $\mathrm{AlO_2^-}$
C. $\mathrm{Al^{3+}}$
D. $\mathrm{Fe^{2+}}$
comment: When the mixture reacts with excess hydrochloric acid, magnesium and aluminum dissolve, forming $\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}$ and $\mathrm{Al^{3+}}$. After adding excess sodium hydroxide, $\mathrm{Al^{3+}}$ forms $\mathrm{AlO_2^-}$ (a soluble aluminate ion), while $\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}$ remains unaffected. Filtering removes any precipitates, leaving $\mathrm{AlO_2^-}$ in the filtrate. Thus, the correct answer is B.

question:
Two equal masses of magnesium are burned separately in sufficient pure oxygen and in air. After the complete reaction, the comparison of the mass of the solid product formed is
A. The mass of the product formed in pure oxygen combustion is larger.
B. The mass of the product formed in air combustion is larger.
C. The two have equal mass.
D. Cannot be determined.
choices: A. The mass of the product formed in pure oxygen combustion is larger.
B. The mass of the product formed in air combustion is larger.
C. The two have equal mass.
D. Cannot be determined.
comment: When magnesium burns in pure oxygen, it reacts completely to form magnesium oxide (MgO). However, in air, due to the presence of nitrogen, magnesium may also form magnesium nitride (Mg₃N₂), which has a different molar mass. The amount of oxygen in air is less, leading to a smaller amount of MgO being formed. Therefore, the mass of the product in pure oxygen combustion is larger, and the correct answer is A.

question:
Among the following elements: \( \text{K} \), \( \text{Na} \), \( \text{Al} \), \( \text{Mg} \), which of the following is the correct order from strongest to weakest metallic activity?
A. ①②③④
B. ①③②④
C. ④③②①
D. ①②④③
choices: A. ①②③④
B. ①③②④
C. ④③②①
D. ①②④③
comment: The metallic activity of elements decreases in the order \( \text{K} > \text{Na} > \text{Mg} > \text{Al} \). Therefore, the correct order from strongest to weakest metallic activity is ①②④③, which corresponds to option D.

question:
Which of the following descriptions is correct?
A. $\text{A. Mg burns in air, and the product is only } \text{MgO.}$
B. $\text{B. During metal welding, filling light bulbs, food storage (e.g., grains, fruits, etc.), nitrogen gas is often used as a protective gas to prevent oxidation or corrosion.}$
C. $\text{C. The reaction rate of iron with hydrochloric acid to produce hydrogen gas: pure iron > cast iron.}$
D. $\text{D. When preparing ferrous hydroxide, adding sodium hydroxide solution dropwise to ferrous sulfate solution with stirring can produce white ferrous hydroxide.}$
choices: A. $\text{A. Mg burns in air, and the product is only } \text{MgO.}$
B. $\text{B. During metal welding, filling light bulbs, food storage (e.g., grains, fruits, etc.), nitrogen gas is often used as a protective gas to prevent oxidation or corrosion.}$
C. $\text{C. The reaction rate of iron with hydrochloric acid to produce hydrogen gas: pure iron > cast iron.}$
D. $\text{D. When preparing ferrous hydroxide, adding sodium hydroxide solution dropwise to ferrous sulfate solution with stirring can produce white ferrous hydroxide.}$
comment: Nitrogen gas is commonly used as a protective atmosphere for processes such as welding, food storage, and filling light bulbs to prevent oxidation or corrosion. Therefore, option B is correct.

question:
Among the following substances: \(\text{① Na}_2\text{SiO}_3\), \(\text{② Al(OH)}_3\), \(\text{③ NH}_4\text{HCO}_3\), \(\text{④ Al}_2\text{O}_3\), \(\text{⑤ NaHSO}_4\), which can react with both acid and \(\text{NaOH}\) solution is:
A. ①②④
B. ②③④
C. ②④⑤
D. All
choices: A. ①②④
B. ②③④
C. ②④⑤
D. All
comment: Substances that can react with both acids and \(\text{NaOH}\) (alkali) are amphoteric compounds. \(\text{② Al(OH)}_3\), \(\text{③ NH}_4\text{HCO}_3\), and \(\text{④ Al}_2\text{O}_3\) exhibit amphoteric behavior, so the correct answer is B.

question:
Aluminum powder and iron(III) oxide powder are mixed to form thermite, and divided into two equal parts. One part is completely reacted at high temperature and then reacts with sufficient hydrochloric acid; the other part is placed in sufficient sodium hydroxide solution to fully react. The mass ratio of gas produced in the two scenarios is
A. 1:1
B. 2:3
C. 3:2
D. 28:9
comment: In the first scenario, the reaction of thermite with hydrochloric acid produces hydrogen gas, while in the second scenario, the reaction with sodium hydroxide also produces hydrogen gas. The stoichiometry of the reactions results in a mass ratio of 2:3 for the hydrogen gas produced, so the correct answer is B.

question:
Aluminum is used as a reducing agent in the smelting of refractory metals because aluminum ()
A. has electrical conductivity
B. has ductility
C. can react with both acids and bases
D. releases a large amount of heat during the oxidation process
choices: A. has electrical conductivity
B. has ductility
C. can react with both acids and bases
D. releases a large amount of heat during the oxidation process
comment: Aluminum is highly reactive and releases a significant amount of heat when oxidized, making it suitable for use as a reducing agent in the smelting of refractory metals. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Two portions of aluminum, one portion reacts with excess \( \text{HCl} \), and the other portion reacts with excess \( \text{NaOH} \) solution. If the volume ratio of produced \( \text{H}_2 \) under the same conditions is 1:1, then the mass ratio of the two portions of aluminum is
A. 1:1
B. 1:2
C. 1:3
D. 2:1
comment: When aluminum reacts with \( \text{HCl} \), the reaction is \( 2\text{Al} + 6\text{HCl} \rightarrow 2\text{AlCl}_3 + 3\text{H}_2 \). When aluminum reacts with \( \text{NaOH} \), the reaction is \( 2\text{Al} + 2\text{NaOH} + 6\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow 2\text{NaAl(OH)}_4 + 3\text{H}_2 \). In both cases, the amount of \( \text{H}_2 \) produced is the same, so the mass of aluminum used in each reaction is also the same, giving a mass ratio of 1:1. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question:
The reason aluminum can exist stably in air is
A. The activity of aluminum is different
B. The reducibility of aluminum is different
C. Aluminum does not react with oxygen
D. Aluminum has an oxide film on its surface
choices: A. The activity of aluminum is different
B. The reducibility of aluminum is different
C. Aluminum does not react with oxygen
D. Aluminum has an oxide film on its surface
comment: Aluminum forms a thin oxide film on its surface when exposed to air, which protects it from further oxidation. This oxide layer prevents further reaction of aluminum with oxygen, allowing aluminum to exist stably in air. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Regarding the reaction of \( \text{Al} \) with heavy water alkali \( \text{NaOD} \) in aqueous solution, which of the following statements is correct?
A. The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{D}_2 \).
B. The hydrogen gas produced contains \( \text{H}_2 \), \( \text{HD} \), and \( \text{D}_2 \).
C. The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{H}_2 \).
D. \( \text{D}_2 \text{C}. \) The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{H}_2\text{D} \). The above statements are all incorrect.
choices: A. The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{D}_2 \).
B. The hydrogen gas produced contains \( \text{H}_2 \), \( \text{HD} \), and \( \text{D}_2 \).
C. The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{H}_2 \).
D. \( \text{D}_2 \text{C}. \) The hydrogen gas produced only contains \( \text{H}_2\text{D} \). The above statements are all incorrect.
comment: When \( \text{Al} \) reacts with \( \text{NaOD} \) in aqueous solution, the hydrogen gas produced consists of \( \text{H}_2 \), \( \text{HD} \), and \( \text{D}_2 \) due to the isotopic exchange between \( \text{H} \) and \( \text{D} \). Thus, the correct answer is B.

question:
In the thermite reaction, aluminum can be used to smelt refractory metals (such as \ce{Fe}, \ce{V}, \ce{Mn}, etc.). Which property of aluminum is exhibited in the reaction?
A. Amphoteric
B. Good electrical conductivity
C. Low melting point
D. Reducibility, releasing a large amount of heat during the reaction
choices: A. Amphoteric
B. Good electrical conductivity
C. Low melting point
D. Reducibility, releasing a large amount of heat during the reaction
comment: In the thermite reaction, aluminum reduces metal oxides to produce metals and releases a large amount of heat. This demonstrates the reducibility of aluminum, which is the correct answer, D.

choices: A. \text{Mg}
B. \text{Al(OH)}_3
C. \text{Al}
D. \text{CO}_2
comment: Sodium hydroxide reacts with \text{Al} to form sodium aluminate, and \text{CO}_2 reacts with \text{NaOH} to form sodium carbonate. \text{Al(OH)}_3 can react with excess \text{NaOH} to form \text{NaAlO}_2. However, \text{Mg} does not react with \text{NaOH} solution, so the correct answer is A.

question:
Which of the following statements about aluminum is incorrect?
A. Aluminum is the most abundant metal element in the Earth's crust.
B. Aluminum has good corrosion resistance because its surface oxide layer can prevent aluminum from coming into contact with oxygen in the air.
C. Aluminum is an active metal, often used as a reducing agent in chemical reactions.
D. Aluminum utensils can be used for cooking or storing alkaline foods for a long time, but they are not suitable for storing acidic foods.
choices: A. Aluminum is the most abundant metal element in the Earth's crust.
B. Aluminum has good corrosion resistance because its surface oxide layer can prevent aluminum from coming into contact with oxygen in the air.
C. Aluminum is an active metal, often used as a reducing agent in chemical reactions.
D. Aluminum utensils can be used for cooking or storing alkaline foods for a long time, but they are not suitable for storing acidic foods.
comment: Aluminum utensils can react with acidic foods, potentially leading to corrosion or contamination. Therefore, statement D is incorrect.

question:
Using the thermite method to reduce the following oxides to produce 1 \text{ mol} of each metal, which consumes the least amount of aluminum:
A. \text{MnO}_2
B. \text{WO}_3
C. \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_3
D. \text{Co}_3\text{O}_4
choices: A. \text{MnO}_2
B. \text{WO}_3
C. \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_3
D. \text{Co}_3\text{O}_4
comment: To determine the amount of aluminum consumed, we need to look at the stoichiometry of the thermite reactions. For each of these reactions, we balance the equation for producing 1 mol of metal from the oxide using aluminum. The molar masses and stoichiometry determine the aluminum consumption. After balancing, it is found that reducing \text{Co}_3\text{O}_4 consumes the least aluminum, so the correct answer is D.

question:
Convert 4 \text{ mol} of metallic \mathrm{Al} completely into \mathrm{Al(OH)_3}. Consuming \mathrm{HCl} \textit{a mol} and \mathrm{NaOH} \textit{b mol}, what is the minimum value of \textit{a + b}?
A. 4
B. 6
C. 8
D. 16
comment: The reaction involves \mathrm{Al} reacting with \mathrm{HCl} and \mathrm{NaOH} to form \mathrm{Al(OH)_3}. The stoichiometric calculations show that the minimum \textit{a + b} is 6, so the correct answer is B.

question:
A 10 g mixture of two metals from \( \text{Zn} \), \( \text{Fe} \), \( \text{Al} \), and \( \text{Mg} \) reacts with enough hydrochloric acid to produce 11.2 L of hydrogen gas at standard conditions. Which metal must be in the mixture?
A. \( \text{Mg} \)
B. \( \text{Al} \)
C. \( \text{Fe} \)
D. \( \text{Zn} \)
choices: A. \( \text{Mg} \)
B. \( \text{Al} \)
C. \( \text{Fe} \)
D. \( \text{Zn} \)
comment: Aluminum (\( \text{Al} \)) reacts with hydrochloric acid to produce hydrogen gas efficiently. Given the volume of hydrogen gas produced, it indicates the presence of \( \text{Al} \) in the mixture. Thus, the correct answer is B.

question:
Equal masses of aluminum react separately with sufficient hydrochloric acid \((\text{HCl})\) and sodium hydroxide \((\text{NaOH})\) solutions. When the aluminum is completely dissolved, what is the molar ratio of \(\text{HCl}\) to \(\text{NaOH}\) consumed in the reactions?
A. 1:1
B. 2:1
C. 1:2
D. 3:1
comment: Aluminum reacts with hydrochloric acid \((\text{HCl})\) according to the equation \(2\text{Al} + 6\text{HCl} \rightarrow 2\text{AlCl}_3 + 3\text{H}_2\), and with sodium hydroxide \((\text{NaOH})\) according to the equation \(2\text{Al} + 2\text{NaOH} + 6\text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow 2\text{Na}[\text{Al(OH)}_4] + 3\text{H}_2\). For equal masses of aluminum, the molar ratio of \(\text{HCl}\) to \(\text{NaOH}\) consumed is \(6:2 = 3:1\). Hence, the correct answer is D.

question:
Which of the following descriptions about the properties of \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is incorrect?
A. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is an amphoteric hydroxide.
B. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is a white gelatinous substance that is sparingly soluble in water.
C. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) can coagulate suspended matter in water and also adsorb pigments.
D. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) dissolves in \( \text{NaOH} \) solution, water, and \( \text{HCl} \).
choices: A. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is an amphoteric hydroxide.
B. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is a white gelatinous substance that is sparingly soluble in water.
C. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) can coagulate suspended matter in water and also adsorb pigments.
D. \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) dissolves in \( \text{NaOH} \) solution, water, and \( \text{HCl} \).
comment: Aluminum hydroxide \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) is an amphoteric substance, which means it can react with both acids and bases. It is sparingly soluble in water and forms a white gelatinous precipitate. It can coagulate suspended matter and adsorb pigments. However, \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) does not dissolve in water; it only dissolves in strong acids (like \( \text{HCl} \)) and strong bases (like \( \text{NaOH} \)), making option D incorrect.

choices: A. \ce{Na}
B. \ce{Fe}
C. \ce{Si}
D. \ce{Cu}
comment: The red color of red coral is caused by the accumulation of \ce{Fe} (iron) on the seabed over a long period. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

choices: A. \mathrm{Na_2O_2}
B. \mathrm{Al_2O_3}
C. \mathrm{Fe_2O_3}
D. \mathrm{CaO}
comment: Amphoteric oxides can react with both acids and bases to form salts. Among the given options, \mathrm{Al_2O_3} is an amphoteric oxide, so the correct answer is B.

question:
To remove a small amount of \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \) mixed in \( \text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3 \), which reagent can be used?
A. Sodium hydroxide solution
B. Sulfuric acid
C. Ammonia
D. Hydrochloric acid
choices: A. Sodium hydroxide solution
B. Sulfuric acid
C. Ammonia
D. Hydrochloric acid
comment: Sodium hydroxide solution can dissolve \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \) while leaving \( \text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3 \) intact, making it the correct choice.

question:
Which of the following substances cannot be prepared through chemical reactions?
A. \text{Fe(OH)}_2
B. \text{Fe(OH)}_3
C. \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3
D. \text{FeCl}_2
choices: A. \text{Fe(OH)}_2
B. \text{Fe(OH)}_3
C. \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3
D. \text{FeCl}_2
comment: Fe(OH)_2 cannot be prepared directly through chemical reactions because it is not stable under standard conditions. The correct answer is A.

question:
The iron compound X is dissolved in hydrochloric acid. Adding potassium thiocyanate solution does not cause a color change. Adding an appropriate amount of ammonia water makes the solution turn blood red. What is X?
A. \text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3
B. \text{FeCl}_3
C. \text{Fe}_3\text{O}_4
D. \text{FeO}
choices: A. \text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3
B. \text{FeCl}_3
C. \text{Fe}_3\text{O}_4
D. \text{FeO}
comment: The solution of FeO in hydrochloric acid forms Fe^{2+}, which does not react with potassium thiocyanate to change color. However, upon adding ammonia water, Fe^{2+} is oxidized to Fe^{3+}, which forms a blood-red complex with thiocyanate ions, indicating X is FeO. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Among the following substances, which one can react with both hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide solution?
A. \( \text{CO}_2 \)
B. \( \text{Mg} \)
C. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \)
D. \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
choices: A. \( \text{CO}_2 \)
B. \( \text{Mg} \)
C. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \)
D. \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
comment: Aluminum oxide (\( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)) is an amphoteric oxide, meaning it can react with both acids (e.g., hydrochloric acid) and bases (e.g., sodium hydroxide). Thus, the correct answer is D.

question:
Aluminum products are not suitable for long-term storage of acidic and alkaline foods because the surface layer of aluminum products is composed of
A. Metallic aluminum
B. Basic oxides
C. Acidic oxides
D. Amphoteric oxides
choices: A. Metallic aluminum
B. Basic oxides
C. Acidic oxides
D. Amphoteric oxides
comment: The surface of aluminum products is covered with a thin layer of amphoteric aluminum oxide \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \), which reacts with both acids and bases. Therefore, aluminum products are not suitable for storing acidic or alkaline foods. The correct answer is D.

question:
Which of the following compounds can react with both hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide solution?
A. ②③④
B. ①②④
C. ①②③
D. ②④⑤
choices: A. ②③④
B. ①②④
C. ①②③
D. ②④⑤
comment: Compounds that can react with both acids and bases are amphoteric. \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) (①) can react with both acids and bases, \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) (②) is amphoteric and can react with both, and \( \text{H}_2\text{N-CH}_2\text{-COOH} \) (④) is an amino acid, which can also react with both. Thus, the correct answer is B (①②④).

question:
Which of the following substances can react with both hydrochloric acid and \( \text{NaOH} \) solution?
A. \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{SiO}_3 \)
C. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \)
D. \( \text{SiO}_2 \)
choices: A. \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{SiO}_3 \)
C. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \)
D. \( \text{SiO}_2 \)
comment: Aluminum oxide (\( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)) is amphoteric, meaning it can react with both acids and bases. It reacts with hydrochloric acid to form \( \text{AlCl}_3 \) and water, and with sodium hydroxide (\( \text{NaOH} \)) to form sodium aluminate (\( \text{NaAlO}_2 \)).

choices: A. \text{Na}
B. \text{Fe}
C. \text{Si}
D. \text{Cu}
comment: The red color in corals is commonly due to the presence of iron compounds. Therefore, the element responsible for the red color is iron (Fe), making the correct answer B.

choices: A. \text{Na}
B. \text{Mg}
C. \text{Fe}
D. \text{Ca}
comment: The red color of the coral is due to the presence of iron oxide, \text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3, which gives it the red appearance. Therefore, the correct element is \text{Fe}, so the answer is C.

question:
The apple juice turns from light green to brown in air. What could be the reason?
A. The \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) in the apple juice is converted to \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \)
B. The apple juice contains \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \)
C. The apple juice contains \( \text{OH}^- \)
D. The apple juice contains \( \text{Na}^+ \)
choices: A. The \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) in the apple juice is converted to \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \)
B. The apple juice contains \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \)
C. The apple juice contains \( \text{OH}^- \)
D. The apple juice contains \( \text{Na}^+ \)
comment: The oxidation of \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) to \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \) can cause a color change from light green to brown. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question:
Copper is one of the earliest metals used by humans. Humans have used their wisdom to extract pure copper from nature and create various types of tools, making significant contributions to human civilization. Based on your knowledge, judge which of the following methods can be used to extract copper:
A. 1. $\mathrm{K} + \mathrm{CuSO_4} \text{ (aqueous solution)}$
B. 2. $\mathrm{CuO} + \mathrm{CO} \text{ (heat)}$
C. 3. $\mathrm{CuO} + \mathrm{H_2} \text{ (heat)}$
D. 4. $\mathrm{Fe} + \mathrm{CuSO_4} \text{ (aqueous solution)}$
choices: A. 1. $\mathrm{K} + \mathrm{CuSO_4} \text{ (aqueous solution)}$
B. 2. $\mathrm{CuO} + \mathrm{CO} \text{ (heat)}$
C. 3. $\mathrm{CuO} + \mathrm{H_2} \text{ (heat)}$
D. 4. $\mathrm{Fe} + \mathrm{CuSO_4} \text{ (aqueous solution)}$
comment: Among the given reactions: (1) Potassium ($\mathrm{K}$) reacts with $\mathrm{CuSO_4}$ solution, but potassium is too reactive and not practical for extracting copper. (2) Copper(II) oxide ($\mathrm{CuO}$) can react with carbon monoxide ($\mathrm{CO}$) when heated to produce copper. (3) Copper(II) oxide ($\mathrm{CuO}$) can react with hydrogen ($\mathrm{H_2}$) when heated to produce copper. (4) Iron ($\mathrm{Fe}$) can displace copper from $\mathrm{CuSO_4}$ solution due to its higher reactivity. Therefore, methods (3) and (4) can be used to extract copper, and the correct answer is C.

question:
To remove a small amount of \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) impurity in the \( \text{FeCl}_2 \) solution, the best method is to add to the solution:
A. Sufficient chlorine gas
B. Sufficient dilute hydrochloric acid
C. Sufficient \( \text{Fe} \) powder
D. Sufficient \( \text{Cu} \) powder
choices: A. Sufficient chlorine gas
B. Sufficient dilute hydrochloric acid
C. Sufficient \( \text{Fe} \) powder
D. Sufficient \( \text{Cu} \) powder
comment: Adding \( \text{Fe} \) powder will reduce \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) to \( \text{FeCl}_2 \), effectively removing the impurity from the solution. Thus, the correct answer is C.

choices: A. \text{NaOH solution}
B. Iron pieces
C. \text{KSCN solution}
D. Starch solution
comment: If \( \text{FeCl}_2 \) has oxidized to \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \), adding \( \text{KSCN} \) solution will form a red complex with \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \), indicating deterioration. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
A solution is added with \( \text{KSCN} \), and no obvious phenomenon is observed. After adding chlorine water, the solution immediately turns blood red, indicating that the original solution must contain which ion?
A. \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \)
B. \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \)
C. \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \)
D. \( \text{Zn}^{2+} \)
comment: When \( \text{KSCN} \) is added, \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) does not react. However, after adding chlorine water, \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \) is oxidized to \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \), which reacts with \( \text{SCN}^- \) to form the blood-red complex \( \text{[Fe(SCN)]^{2+}} \). Thus, the original solution must contain \( \text{Fe}^{2+} \). The correct answer is C.

question:
Aluminum belongs to which of the following categories?
A. Heavy metals, Light metals, Common metals
B. Light metals, Rare metals, Colored metals
C. Light metals, Common metals, Colored metals
D. Light metals, Rare metals, Common metals
choices: A. Heavy metals, Light metals, Common metals
B. Light metals, Rare metals, Colored metals
C. Light metals, Common metals, Colored metals
D. Light metals, Rare metals, Common metals
comment: Aluminum is classified as a light metal, a common metal, and a colored metal. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
Which of the following statements about ferrous sulfate is correct?
A. The main purpose of soaking iron filings in acetic acid solution is to remove acidic substances.
B. Iron filings treated with sodium carbonate solution should be immediately added with excess sulfuric acid to ensure complete dissolution.
C. After treating iron filings with sulfuric acid, they must be filtered while hot.
D. Ferrous sulfate solution should be evaporated in a dish until concentrated and dry.
choices: A. The main purpose of soaking iron filings in acetic acid solution is to remove acidic substances.
B. Iron filings treated with sodium carbonate solution should be immediately added with excess sulfuric acid to ensure complete dissolution.
C. After treating iron filings with sulfuric acid, they must be filtered while hot.
D. Ferrous sulfate solution should be evaporated in a dish until concentrated and dry.
comment: After treating iron filings with sulfuric acid, hot filtration is necessary to ensure that the reaction is complete and the solution is clear. Thus, the correct answer is C.

question:
Add ammonia water to the test tube containing copper sulfate solution, first a difficultly soluble precipitate is formed, and continue to add ammonia water, the precipitate dissolves to give a deep blue transparent solution. Which of the following statements about this phenomenon is correct?
A.  There is no precipitate in the solution after the reaction, so the concentration of \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \) before and after the reaction does not change.
B.  The precipitate dissolves to form a deep blue complex ion \([\text{Cu}(	ext{NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\).
C.  The precipitate formed by adding ammonia water to the copper sulfate solution is copper hydroxide. Continuing to add ammonia water causes the precipitate to dissolve, indicating that copper hydroxide is an amphoteric hydroxide.
D.  In \([\text{Cu}(	ext{NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\) ion, \(\text{Cu}^{2+}\) provides the lone pair of electrons, and \(\text{NH}_3\) provides the empty orbital.
choices: A.  There is no precipitate in the solution after the reaction, so the concentration of \( \text{Cu}^{2+} \) before and after the reaction does not change.
B.  The precipitate dissolves to form a deep blue complex ion \([\text{Cu}(	ext{NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\).

C.  The precipitate formed by adding ammonia water to the copper sulfate solution is copper hydroxide. Continuing to add ammonia water causes the precipitate to dissolve, indicating that copper hydroxide is an amphoteric hydroxide.
D.  In \([\text{Cu}(	ext{NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\) ion, \(\text{Cu}^{2+}\) provides the lone pair of electrons, and \(\text{NH}_3\) provides the empty orbital.
comment: The precipitate dissolves to form the deep blue complex ion \([\text{Cu}(	ext{NH}_3)_4]^{2+}\), which is characteristic of the formation of this complex. Therefore, the correct statement is B.

question:
Copper does not dissolve in dilute nitric acid or in NaNO_{3} solution, but it can dissolve in their mixed solution. Now, when 30 mL of 2 mol/L dilute nitric acid is mixed with 1.7 g of NaNO_{3} crystals and fully dissolved, what is the maximum mass of copper that can be dissolved in this mixed solution?
A. 0.045 mol
B. 0.03 mol
C. 0.0225 mol
D. 0.02 mol
choices: A. 0.045 mol
B. 0.03 mol
D. 0.02 mol
comment: The mixed solution contains 0.03 mol of nitric acid and enough nitrate to ensure the reaction. The reaction is Cu + 4HNO_{3} \rightarrow Cu(NO_{3})_{2} + 2NO_{2} + 2H_{2}O, consuming 4 moles of HNO_{3} per mole of Cu. Thus, 0.03 mol of HNO_{3} can dissolve 0.03/4 = 0.0075 mol of Cu. However, upon reevaluation of the nitrate supply and possible reactions, the answer is 0.03 mol.

choices: A. \text{A. Copper sulfate solution}
B. \text{B. Hydrochloric acid}
C. \text{C. Dilute nitric acid}
D. \text{D. Silver nitrate solution}
comment: Dilute nitric acid can dissolve brass (copper-zinc alloy) but not gold or gold-silver alloys. If the medal is made of brass, it will react with dilute nitric acid, proving Person C's speculation wrong. Thus, the correct answer is C.

question:
After the following experiments, the mass of copper must have changed. Which of the following is correct?
A.  Copper wire is burned in air and quickly inserted into ethanol.
B.  Copper sheet is placed into an oxidizing nitric acid ($HNO_3$) solution.
C.  A mixture of copper and iron is placed into dilute sulfuric acid ($H_2SO_4$).
D.  A galvanic cell composed of copper, zinc, and dilute sulfuric acid ($H_2SO_4$) discharges.
choices: A.  Copper wire is burned in air and quickly inserted into ethanol.
B.  Copper sheet is placed into an oxidizing nitric acid ($HNO_3$) solution.
C.  A mixture of copper and iron is placed into dilute sulfuric acid ($H_2SO_4$).
D.  A galvanic cell composed of copper, zinc, and dilute sulfuric acid ($H_2SO_4$) discharges.
comment: When copper is placed into oxidizing nitric acid ($HNO_3$), a redox reaction occurs, and the copper reacts to form copper ions ($Cu^{2+}$), resulting in a change in the mass of copper. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question:
Among the following acids, 3.2 g of copper \((\ce{Cu})\) is added. Under the same conditions, which acid produces the largest volume of gas after the reaction?
A. Concentrated \(\ce{H2SO4}\)
B. Dilute \(\ce{H2SO4}\)
C. Concentrated \(\ce{HNO3}\)
D. Dilute \(\ce{HNO3}\)
choices: A. Concentrated \(\ce{H2SO4}\)
B. Dilute \(\ce{H2SO4}\)
C. Concentrated \(\ce{HNO3}\)
D. Dilute \(\ce{HNO3}\)
comment: Copper \((\ce{Cu})\) reacts with concentrated \(\ce{HNO3}\) to produce \(\ce{NO2}\), and the reaction produces a large amount of gas. Among the given acids, concentrated \(\ce{HNO3}\) leads to the largest gas volume, so the correct answer is C.

question:
Comrade Mao Zedong once wrote a brilliant poem that includes the lines 'red orange yellow green blue purple, who holds the colorful brocade when dancing in the air'. According to the colors of the substances listed below, the sequence arrangement according to 'red orange yellow green blue purple' is
A. ① ② ③ ④ ⑤ ⑥ ⑦
B. ⑧ ① ⑤ ⑥ ④ ⑦ ③
C. ⑨ ⑧ ⑤ ⑥ ② ③ ①
D. ⑧ ① ⑤ ⑥ ④ ② ③
choices: A. ① ② ③ ④ ⑤ ⑥ ⑦
B. ⑧ ① ⑤ ⑥ ④ ⑦ ③
C. ⑨ ⑧ ⑤ ⑥ ② ③ ①
D. ⑧ ① ⑤ ⑥ ④ ② ③
comment: The colors of the substances are as follows: ① Clear water (colorless), ② \(\text{CuSO}_4\) (blue), ③ \(\text{KMnO}_4\) (purple), ④ \(\text{CuO}\) (black), ⑤ \(\text{AgI}\) (yellow), ⑥ \(\text{FeSO}_4\cdot7\text{H}_2\text{O}\) (green), ⑦ \(\text{CuSO}_4\cdot5\text{H}_2\text{O}\) (blue), ⑧ \(\text{HgO}\) (orange), ⑨ \(\text{CuS}\) (black). The correct sequence according to the colors 'red orange yellow green blue purple' is ⑧ (orange) ① (colorless) ⑤ (yellow) ⑥ (green) ④ (blue/black) ⑦ (blue) ③ (purple), so the correct answer is B.

choices: A. \mathrm{KSCN}
B. \mathrm{BaCl_2}
C. \mathrm{NaOH}
D. \mathrm{HCl}
comment: Adding \mathrm{NaOH} can distinguish the given solutions due to the different reactions that occur with each compound, such as precipitate formation or color change. Thus, the correct answer is C.

question:
Which of the following descriptions about sodium is correct?
A. Sodium is a silver-white metal with high hardness.
B. When sodium metal is placed on a gauze and heated with an alcohol lamp, it burns intensely, producing a yellow flame and forming a pale yellow solid.
C. Sodium metal burns in air to form sodium oxide.
D. Sodium metal has a very high melting point.
choices: A. Sodium is a silver-white metal with high hardness.
B. When sodium metal is placed on a gauze and heated with an alcohol lamp, it burns intensely, producing a yellow flame and forming a pale yellow solid.
C. Sodium metal burns in air to form sodium oxide.
D. Sodium metal has a very high melting point.
comment: When sodium metal is heated, it burns intensely with a characteristic yellow flame, forming sodium peroxide, which is a pale yellow solid. Thus, option B is correct.

question:
To prove that a solution contains \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \), which of the following methods is correct?
A. Add iron powder
B. Add dilute sulfuric acid
C. Add ammonia water
D. Add \( \text{KSCN} \) solution
choices: A. Add iron powder
B. Add dilute sulfuric acid
C. Add ammonia water
D. Add \( \text{KSCN} \) solution
comment: Adding \( \text{KSCN} \) solution to a solution containing \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \) will result in a blood-red complex, confirming the presence of \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \). Thus, the correct answer is D.

question:
Which of the following reagents can be used to test whether the long-stored laboratory \( \text{FeSO}_4 \) solution contains \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \)?
A. Stone blue reagent
B. Ethanol reagent
C. Freshly prepared lime water
D. \( \text{KSCN} \) solution
choices: A. Stone blue reagent
B. Ethanol reagent
C. Freshly prepared lime water
D. \( \text{KSCN} \) solution
comment: The \( \text{KSCN} \) solution can form a blood-red complex with \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \), indicating the presence of \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Which of the following substances cannot react with \(\text{NaOH}\)?
A. Aspirin
B. Quartz
C. Aluminum oxide
D. Sucrose
choices: A. Aspirin
B. Quartz
C. Aluminum oxide
D. Sucrose
comment: Quartz is a form of silicon dioxide (\(\text{SiO}_2\)) which is very stable and does not react with \(\text{NaOH}\). Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question:
Which of the following properties does not belong to the common properties of metals?
A. Conductivity and thermal conductivity
B. Metallic luster
C. Relatively high melting point
D. Ductility
choices: A. Conductivity and thermal conductivity
B. Metallic luster
C. Relatively high melting point
D. Ductility
comment: Metals typically have properties such as conductivity, metallic luster, and ductility. However, having a high melting point is not a property shared by all metals, as some metals have low melting points. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct?
A.  Metallic copper, when placed in humid air, will be corroded, forming green patina which is basic copper carbonate \((Cu_2(OH)_2CO_3)\).
B.  Metal oxides are always acidic oxides.
C.  Brass (copper-zinc alloy) is a type of composite material.
D.  Metallic sodium can be stored in anhydrous ethanol.
choices: A.  Metallic copper, when placed in humid air, will be corroded, forming green patina which is basic copper carbonate \((Cu_2(OH)_2CO_3)\).
B.  Metal oxides are always acidic oxides.
C.  Brass (copper-zinc alloy) is a type of composite material.
D.  Metallic sodium can be stored in anhydrous ethanol.
comment: When metallic copper is exposed to humid air, it reacts with water, carbon dioxide, and oxygen to form green patina, which is basic copper carbonate \((Cu_2(OH)_2CO_3)\). This statement is correct, so the answer is A.

question:
FeCl$_3$ solution is used to etch copper on printed circuit boards, and iron powder is added to the solution. After the iron powder is fully reacted, which analysis of the solution is reasonable?
A. If there is no solid residue, there must be Fe$^{3+}$ in the solution.
B. If there is solid present, there must be Fe$^{2+}$ in the solution.
C. If there is Cu$^{2+}$ in the solution, there must be no solid precipitate.
D. If there is Fe$^{2+}$ in the solution, Cu must be precipitated.
choices: A. If there is no solid residue, there must be Fe$^{3+}$ in the solution.
B. If there is solid present, there must be Fe$^{2+}$ in the solution.
C. If there is Cu$^{2+}$ in the solution, there must be no solid precipitate.
D. If there is Fe$^{2+}$ in the solution, Cu must be precipitated.
comment: When FeCl$_3$ reacts with iron powder, Fe$^{3+}$ is reduced to Fe$^{2+}$. If there is solid present after the reaction, it indicates that not all Fe$^{3+}$ has been reduced, hence Fe$^{2+}$ must be present in the solution. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question:
Which of the following substances can react with \( \text{NaOH} \) solution and also react with acid?
A. ① \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \)
B. ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
C. ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
D. ① \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
choices: A. ① \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \)
B. ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
C. ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
D. ① \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \) ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \) ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \) ④ \( \text{Al} \) ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \)
comment: All the substances ① \( \text{NaHCO}_3 \), ② \( (\text{NH}_4)_2\text{CO}_3 \), ③ \( \text{Al(OH)}_3 \), ④ \( \text{Al} \), and ⑤ \( \text{Al}_2\text{O}_3 \) can react with \( \text{NaOH} \) and also with acids. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
It is known that the simple substances and compounds of lithium and sodium have many similar properties. Therefore, it can be inferred that among the following descriptions about lithium and its compounds, the correct one is
A. $\text{LiOH}$ does not decompose when heated.
B. $\text{Li}_2\text{CO}_3$ does not decompose when heated.
C. $\text{Li}$ burns in oxygen to form $\text{Li}_2\text{O}_2$.
D. $\text{Li}$ reacts with dilute sulfuric acid to form $\text{Li}_2\text{SO}_4$.
choices: A. $\text{LiOH}$ does not decompose when heated.
B. $\text{Li}_2\text{CO}_3$ does not decompose when heated.
C. $\text{Li}$ burns in oxygen to form $\text{Li}_2\text{O}_2$.
D. $\text{Li}$ reacts with dilute sulfuric acid to form $\text{Li}_2\text{SO}_4$.
comment: Lithium reacts with dilute sulfuric acid to form $\text{Li}_2\text{SO}_4$. This is the correct statement. The other statements are incorrect: $\text{LiOH}$ does decompose when heated, $\text{Li}_2\text{CO}_3$ decomposes when heated, and $\text{Li}$ burns in oxygen to form $\text{Li}_2\text{O}$, not $\text{Li}_2\text{O}_2$.

question:
A certain mixed gas may contain \(\text{N}_2\), \(\text{HCl}\), and \(\text{CO}\). The mixed gas is passed successively through sufficient \(\text{NaHCO}_3\) solution and heated \(\text{CuO}\), during which the gas volume does not change. Then, it is passed through sufficient solid \(\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2\), causing the gas volume to decrease. Finally, the gas is fully reacted with heated copper wire, after which the gas volume decreases again but some gas still remains. Regarding the composition of the mixed gas, which of the following is correct?
A.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be present, \(\text{HCl}\) must be present, \(\text{CO}\) is absent
B.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be present, at least one of \(\text{CO}\) and \(\text{HCl}\) must be present
C.  \(\text{N}_2\), \(\text{CO}\), and \(\text{HCl}\) must all be present
D.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be absent, at least one of \(\text{CO}\) and \(\text{HCl}\) must be present
choices: A.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be present, \(\text{HCl}\) must be present, \(\text{CO}\) is absent
B.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be present, at least one of \(\text{CO}\) and \(\text{HCl}\) must be present
C.  \(\text{N}_2\), \(\text{CO}\), and \(\text{HCl}\) must all be present
D.  \(\text{N}_2\) must be absent, at least one of \(\text{CO}\) and \(\text{HCl}\) must be present
comment: When the mixed gas is passed through \(\text{NaHCO}_3\) solution, \(\text{HCl}\) reacts with it, and no change in gas volume indicates \(\text{HCl}\) may or may not be present. Heating with \(\text{CuO}\) removes \(\text{CO}\) if present, and the gas volume decreases when passed through \(\text{Na}_2\text{O}_2\), indicating \(\text{CO}\) or \(\text{HCl}\) may be present. \(\text{N}_2\) remains unreacted throughout. Therefore, \(\text{N}_2\) must be present, and at least one of \(\text{CO}\) or \(\text{HCl}\) must also be present. The correct answer is B.

question:
X, Y, and Z are all short-period elements. It is known that the element X has an isotope that does not contain neutrons. The number of valence electrons in the atom of element Y is twice the number of electrons in its penultimate shell. The number of valence electrons in the atom of element Z is three times the number of electrons in its penultimate shell. Among the following chemical formulas ① \( \text{XYZ}_3 \), ② \( \text{X}_2\text{Y}\text{Z}_2 \), ③ \( \text{X}_2\text{Y}\text{Z}_3 \), ④ \( \text{X}_2\text{Y}_2\text{Z}_2 \), ⑤ \( \text{X}_2\text{Y}_2\text{Z}_4 \), and ⑥ \( \text{X}_4\text{Y}_2\text{Z}_2 \), which one does not exist as a molecule? ( )
A. ①②
B. ④⑥
C. ③⑤
D. ②④
choices: A. ①②
B. ④⑥
C. ③⑤
D. ②④
comment: Element X is hydrogen (H) since it has an isotope without neutrons. Element Y could be oxygen (O), as its valence electrons (6) are twice the number in its penultimate shell (2). Element Z could be nitrogen (N), as its valence electrons (5) are three times the number in its penultimate shell (2). Based on these properties, the molecular combinations \( \text{XYZ}_3 \) and \( \text{X}_2\text{Y}\text{Z}_2 \) are not valid chemical formulas, so the correct answer is A.

question:
When \( \text{CO}_2 \) is passed into an aqueous solution containing 0.8 g of \( \text{NaOH} \), the solution is evaporated under reduced pressure after the reaction, yielding 1.37 g of solid. What is the mass of \( \text{CO}_2 \) passed in?
A. 0.44 g
B. 0.66 g
C. 0.88 g
D. None of the above
choices: D. None of the above
comment: The reaction between \( \text{NaOH} \) and \( \text{CO}_2 \) can produce \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \). The balanced chemical equation is \( 2\text{NaOH} + \text{CO}_2 \rightarrow \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + \text{H}_2\text{O} \). The molar mass of \( \text{NaOH} \) is 40 g/mol, so 0.8 g corresponds to 0.02 mol. According to the stoichiometry, 0.02 mol of \( \text{NaOH} \) would react with 0.01 mol of \( \text{CO}_2 \). The molar mass of \( \text{CO}_2 \) is 44 g/mol, so 0.01 mol corresponds to 0.44 g. However, the solid obtained is \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) which has a molar mass of 106 g/mol. The mass of \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) formed is 1.37 g corresponds to 0.0129 mol, which indicates 0.0129 mol of \( \text{CO}_2 \) was used. This corresponds to 0.66 g of \( \text{CO}_2 \), so the correct answer is B.

question:
10 g of impure \( \mathrm{CaCO_3} \) reacts with sufficient hydrochloric acid under standard conditions, releasing 2.24 L of \( \mathrm{CO_2} \). Determine the composition of the impurities.
A. \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{KHCO_3} \)
B. \( \mathrm{K_2CO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \)
C. \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \)
D. Cannot be determined
choices: A. \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{KHCO_3} \)
B. \( \mathrm{K_2CO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \)
C. \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \)
D. Cannot be determined
comment: The molar volume of \( \mathrm{CO_2} \) under standard conditions is 22.4 L/mol. The given 2.24 L of \( \mathrm{CO_2} \) corresponds to 0.1 mol. Assuming complete reaction, 0.1 mol of \( \mathrm{CaCO_3} \) would weigh 10 g if it were pure. However, impurities such as \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) can also release \( \mathrm{CO_2} \) on reaction, and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \) does not react with acid. Thus, the impurities are \( \mathrm{MgCO_3} \) and \( \mathrm{SiO_2} \).

question:
Currently, relevant departments have decided that driving after drinking alcohol will be severely punished. Police often use a 'breathalyzer' to check for drunk driving. The reaction principle is \[ \text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{OH} + 4\text{CrO}_3 + 6\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4 = 2X + 2\text{CO}_2 + 9\text{H}_2\text{O} \]. In the reaction, the red \( \text{CrO}_3 \) is transformed into a green compound X, what is the chemical formula of X?
A. Cr_2O_3
B. CrSO_3
C. Cr_2(SO_4)_3
D. Cr_2S_3
choices: A. Cr_2O_3
B. CrSO_3
D. Cr_2S_3
comment: In the reaction, \( \text{CrO}_3 \) is reduced to \( \text{Cr}_2(\text{SO}_4)_3 \), which is green. Hence, the correct answer is C.

choices: A. \text{FeS}
B. \text{FeS}_2
C. \text{FeO}
D. \text{Fe}_2\text{S}_3
comment: The chemical equation \(2R + 2H_2O + 7O_2 = 2FeSO_4 + 2H_2SO_4\) suggests that R contains sulfur and iron. By balancing the sulfur atoms, \(R\) is determined to be \(\text{FeS}_2\), as each molecule of \(\text{FeS}_2\) provides two sulfur atoms, which matches the stoichiometry of the reaction. Thus, the correct answer is B.

choices: A. \text{NaOH}
B. \text{Na}_2\text{C}
C. \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_2
D. \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3
comment: The reaction \(2 \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 + 2 \text{CO}_2 = 2 \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 + \text{O}_2\) shows that the product \(X\) is \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
Information that can be obtained from the chemical formula "\text{CO}_2" includes
A. 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7
B. 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7
C. 1, 3, 4, 7, 8
D. 1, 2, 4, 6, 7, 8
comment: The chemical formula \text{CO}_2 represents carbon dioxide, a compound consisting of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms. It is an oxide of carbon, and its molecular weight is 44. The elements in carbon dioxide are carbon and oxygen, and the mass ratio of carbon to oxygen is 3:8. Therefore, the correct information is represented by options 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 7, making the correct answer A.

question:
The long-march rocket propellant for the "Shenzhou I" launch is unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine (X), and the oxidizer is dinitrogen tetroxide ($N_2O_4$). The reaction equation is: $X + 2N_2O_4 = 3N_2 + 2CO_2 + 4H_2O$. The chemical formula of X is
A. \text{H}_2
B. \text{CH}_4
C. \text{C}_2\text{H}_8\text{N}
D. \text{C}_2\text{H}_8\text{N}_2
choices: A. \text{H}_2
B. \text{CH}_4
C. \text{C}_2\text{H}_8\text{N}
D. \text{C}_2\text{H}_8\text{N}_2
comment: The chemical formula for unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine is $\text{C}_2\text{H}_8\text{N}_2$. The balanced reaction with $N_2O_4$ matches the given equation, so the correct answer is D.

question:
When the air is heavily polluted by \( SO_2 \), powder of substance \( X \) can be sprayed via aircraft to significantly reduce the \( SO_2 \) content in the air. The reaction that occurs is: \( 2X + 2SO_2 + O_2 \rightarrow 2CaSO_4 + 2CO_2 \). What is the chemical formula of \( X \)?
A. \( CaO \)
B. \( CaCO_3 \)
C. \( Ca(OH)_2 \)
D. \( Na_2CO_3 \)
choices: A. \( CaO \)
B. \( CaCO_3 \)
comment: The reaction shows that \( X \) reacts with \( SO_2 \) and \( O_2 \) to form \( CaSO_4 \) and \( CO_2 \). This indicates that \( X \) must be a compound containing \( CO_3^{2-} \) which can release \( CO_2 \) during the reaction. Among the options, \( CaCO_3 \) fits this condition. Thus, the correct answer is B.

question:
Which of the following statements about metallic sodium is correct?
A. Metallic sodium is easily oxidized by oxygen in the air, so it is usually stored under water seal.
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) are both basic oxides.
C. When metallic sodium is added to \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) solution, a red precipitate forms.
D. When metallic sodium is cut, its surface quickly darkens, so \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) is gray-black in color.
choices: A. Metallic sodium is easily oxidized by oxygen in the air, so it is usually stored under water seal.
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) and \( \text{Na}_2\text{O}_2 \) are both basic oxides.
C. When metallic sodium is added to \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) solution, a red precipitate forms.
D. When metallic sodium is cut, its surface quickly darkens, so \( \text{Na}_2\text{O} \) is gray-black in color.
comment: When metallic sodium is added to \( \text{FeCl}_3 \) solution, a red precipitate of \( \text{Fe} \) is formed due to the reduction of \( \text{Fe}^{3+} \) to \( \text{Fe} \). This makes the correct answer C.

question:
Which of the following substances has a chemical formula consistent with its name?
A. Quicklime $\text{CaCO}_3$
B. Slaked lime $\text{Ca(OH)}_2$
C. Magnetite $\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3$
D. Limestone $\text{CaO}$
choices: A. Quicklime $\text{CaCO}_3$
B. Slaked lime $\text{Ca(OH)}_2$
C. Magnetite $\text{Fe}_2\text{O}_3$
D. Limestone $\text{CaO}$
comment: Slaked lime is correctly represented by the chemical formula $\text{Ca(OH)}_2$. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question:
In the experiment of extracting iodine from seaweed, which of the following instrument selections is incorrect?
A. Use a balance to weigh 3.0 g of seaweed
B. Burn the seaweed in a crucible
C. Use a separatory funnel to separate seaweed ash and aqueous solution
D. Oxidize \( \text{I}^- \) with \( \text{H}_2\text{O}_2 \) in a beaker
choices: A. Use a balance to weigh 3.0 g of seaweed
B. Burn the seaweed in a crucible
C. Use a separatory funnel to separate seaweed ash and aqueous solution
D. Oxidize \( \text{I}^- \) with \( \text{H}_2\text{O}_2 \) in a beaker
comment: The use of a separatory funnel is incorrect for separating seaweed ash and aqueous solution because a separatory funnel is typically used for separating immiscible liquids, not solids and liquids. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question:
A, B, C, and D are four different colorless solutions: $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, $\text{AgNO}_3$, $\text{BaCl}_2$, and hydrochloric acid. The phenomena when they react pairwise are as follows: A + B → precipitate; A + C → precipitate; B + D → colorless and odorless gas. What is the order of solutions A, B, C, and D?
A. $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{AgNO}_3$
B. $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, $\text{AgNO}_3$, hydrochloric acid
C. $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{AgNO}_3$, $\text{BaCl}_2$
D. $\text{AgNO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$
choices: A. $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{AgNO}_3$
B. $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, $\text{AgNO}_3$, hydrochloric acid
C. $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{AgNO}_3$, $\text{BaCl}_2$
D. $\text{AgNO}_3$, hydrochloric acid, $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$
comment: The reactions suggest that A + B and A + C give precipitates, indicating that A and B or C contain ions that form insoluble salts. B + D producing a colorless gas suggests that B is $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$ and D is hydrochloric acid, forming $\text{CO}_2$ gas. Therefore, the order is: $\text{BaCl}_2$, $\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3$, $\text{AgNO}_3$, hydrochloric acid.

question:
When metallic sodium is exposed to air for a long period, it will eventually turn into which of the following?
A. \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{O} \)
B. \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{O}_{2} \)
C. \( \text{NaOH} \)
D. \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{CO}_{3} \)
choices: A. \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{O} \)
C. \( \text{NaOH} \)
D. \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{CO}_{3} \)
comment: Metallic sodium reacts with oxygen and moisture in the air, leading to a series of chemical reactions. Over time, it reacts with \( \text{CO}_{2} \) in the air to form \( \text{Na}_{2}\text{CO}_{3} \). Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
There are two solutions with equal concentrations. When mixed in equal volumes, a white precipitate forms. After adding excess \( \text{HNO}_3 \), the precipitate disappears and gas is released. Then, after adding \( \text{AgNO}_3 \) solution, a white precipitate forms again. These two solutions are
A. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{Ca(OH)}_2 \)
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{CaCl}_2 \)
C. \( \text{NaOH} \) and \( \text{CuSO}_4 \)
D. \( \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 \) and \( \text{Ba(NO}_3)_2 \)
choices: A. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{Ca(OH)}_2 \)
B. \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{CaCl}_2 \)
C. \( \text{NaOH} \) and \( \text{CuSO}_4 \)
D. \( \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 \) and \( \text{Ba(NO}_3)_2 \)
comment: The initial white precipitate is likely \( \text{CaCO}_3 \) formed from \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \) and \( \text{CaCl}_2 \). Upon adding \( \text{HNO}_3 \), \( \text{CaCO}_3 \) dissolves releasing \( \text{CO}_2 \) gas. Then, adding \( \text{AgNO}_3 \) forms \( \text{AgCl} \) as a white precipitate, confirming the presence of \( \text{Cl}^- \) ions. Thus, the correct answer is B.

choices: A. Ba\left(\text{NO}_3\right)_2 \text{ solution}
B. Ba\left(\text{OH}\right)_2 \text{ solution}
C. Ag\text{NO}_3 \text{ solution}
D. \text{NaOH solution}
comment: Ba(OH)_2 solution can distinguish between NH_4Cl, K_2SO_4, NaCl, and (NH_4)_2SO_4. It reacts with NH_4Cl and (NH_4)_2SO_4 to release NH_3 gas, while it forms a white precipitate with K_2SO_4. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question:
Which of the following solutions can be used to distinguish between 0.1 mol/L \( \text{Na}_2\text{S} \), \( \text{NaI} \), \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \), \( \text{NaAlO}_2 \), and \( \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 \)?
A.  Limewater solution
B.  Chlorine water solution
C.  Ammonia water
D.  Ferric sulfate solution
choices: A.  Limewater solution
B.  Chlorine water solution
C.  Ammonia water
D.  Ferric sulfate solution
comment: Ferric sulfate solution (\( \text{Fe}_2\text{(SO}_4)_3 \)) reacts with \( \text{Na}_2\text{S} \), \( \text{NaI} \), \( \text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3 \), \( \text{NaAlO}_2 \), and \( \text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4 \) differently, allowing one to distinguish between them. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

question:
A bag of solid powder may contain one or several of \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\), and \(\text{CuCl}_2\). The composition is unknown. The following experiment is performed:

(1) Take a small amount of the solid powder, add sufficient water, stir, and let it settle. A white precipitate is formed, and the supernatant is a colorless solution.

(2) Filter, then add excess \(\text{HNO}_3\) to the white precipitate. Part of the precipitate dissolves, and a colorless gas is produced.

Based on the above experiment, the correct determination of the original solid powder is ______.
A. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\), and possibly \(\text{CuCl}_2\)
B. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), definitely not \(\text{CuCl}_2\), possibly \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
C. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), \(\text{CuCl}_2\); \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
D. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{NaCl}\), definitely \(\text{CuCl}_2\), possibly \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
choices: A. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\), and possibly \(\text{CuCl}_2\)
B. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), definitely not \(\text{CuCl}_2\), possibly \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
C. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{Na}_2\text{SO}_4\), \(\text{NaCl}\), \(\text{CuCl}_2\); \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
D. \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\), \(\text{NaCl}\), definitely \(\text{CuCl}_2\), possibly \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\)
comment: Upon adding \(\text{HNO}_3\) to the white precipitate, the fact that part of the precipitate dissolves and a colorless gas is produced suggests the presence of \(\text{Na}_2\text{CO}_3\) (which reacts with acid to produce \(\text{CO}_2\)). The absence of blue or colored substances suggests \(\text{CuCl}_2\) is not present. Thus, \(\text{NH}_4\text{Cl}\) might be present. The correct answer is B.

question:
The boiling point of hydrogen peroxide \( \text{H}_2\text{O}_2 \) is higher than that of water, but it is easily decomposed by heat. In a certain chemical plant, a 7-8% \( \text{H}_2\text{O}_2 \) solution is first prepared, and then it is concentrated into a 30% solution. What is the appropriate method to achieve this?
A.  Evaporation under normal pressure
B.  Evaporation under reduced pressure
C.  Evaporation under normal pressure with the addition of slaked lime
D.  Evaporation under increased pressure
choices: A.  Evaporation under normal pressure
B.  Evaporation under reduced pressure
C.  Evaporation under normal pressure with the addition of slaked lime
D.  Evaporation under increased pressure
comment: Hydrogen peroxide \( \text{H}_2\text{O}_2 \) decomposes easily when heated. To concentrate its solution, evaporation under reduced pressure is used to lower the boiling point and avoid decomposition. Thus, the correct answer is B.
